Frances Farmer.Action: Reads aloud from her diary in a gentle manner, with an older woman listening and nodding
Reflects on spiritual ideas and expresses wonder about God's care for all
Smiles slightly at her father after he kisses her on the head.
Reads aloud from her diary expressing doubt about God and a sense of disillusionment, causing shock among the audience.
Reads her diary aloud thoughtfully at a family gathering, expressing complex personal reflections on faith and life.
Speaks at a school auditorium podium in a national essay competition, articulating her own reasoned conclusions independently.
Questions traditional beliefs about God and life with confidence and intellectual curiosity.
Expresses an emerging skepticism about religion that surprises and unsettles the audience and family members.
Feels proud that she uncovered the truth on her own without help from anyone.
Stares back dumbfounded at a hostile woman’s condemnation without responding.
Closes her notebook and looks up waiting for a response after sharing her ideas.
Refuses to engage with Harry aggressively, keeps control of the interaction, and uses humor and caution to assess him (examines him, considers frisking him, then pulls away).
Initially tries to avoid interaction by walking away, but ultimately decides to talk, showing some openness despite suspicion.
Shakes her head and says 'Bye Emma' but does not attempt to engage, indicating possible social hesitation or withdrawal.
Speaks bluntly and somewhat confrontationally to Harry, expressing frustration and skepticism about the news and attention, demonstrating awareness but also defensiveness.
Takes the check discreetly and puts it in her pocket out of sight.
Humbly downplays her role in winning the essay contest despite her father's praise.
Asks her father about Harry York and discusses sensitive topics cautiously.
Watches her parents argue with concern, asks her father not to leave early because of her mother.
Shakes her head as her father leaves, rejecting his advice to just walk away from conflict.
Expresses deep emotion and tenderness on stage, wiping away tears and embracing fellow actor as part of performance
Takes Harry's arm and accepts his offer to leave the party, showing decisiveness and social awareness.
Expresses uncertainty about going to New York and desire to handle things quietly, indicating internal conflict and some self-doubt.
Engages thoughtfully in conversation, laughs appropriately, and considers advice, showing social and emotional intelligence.
Admits to wanting many things but seems unsure about what she really wants, indicating indecision.
Asks her father for guidance and openly expresses her intentions despite opposition.
Responds calmly and clearly to reporters amidst pressure.
Dismisses others' attempts to control her life and shows indifference to their concerns.
Ignores a man rubbing her arm, grimaces but pays no attention, then notices a fellow student and stares at him briefly before focusing back on the stage.
Playfully grimaces when water lands on her face; searches for water pistol assailant while on phone, showing playful and lighthearted demeanor.
Playfully covers receiver and calls out to Dick, showing informal, friendly tone.
Pays very close attention in acting class and makes notes despite distractions; ignores inappropriate behavior from a man next to her
Attempts to advance career by moving from Broadway to seeking film stardom in the west
Playfully handles water being sprayed on her face and remains engaged on phone conversation
Insists she will not change her name despite external pressures
Engages playfully in a water battle with Dick from drama class, calls him 'handsome' and concedes playfully.
Laughs openly after breaking character in a scene, showing innocence and approachability.
Acknowledges her growing involvement by doing bits now, showing progress and engagement in her work.
Assertively critiques her wardrobe to better fit her character’s situation on set, demonstrating attention to detail and understanding of her role.
Acknowledges the type of ability Harry is interested in with a smile, showing social awareness but avoiding direct confrontation.
Discloses meeting someone seriously despite Harry’s joking, showing maturity in communication.
Does not respond to Harry's joke about actors being phonies, showing restraint and emotional control.
Responds politely to Bebe's compliment about her looks ('Thank you --')
Expresses genuine interest in the film project based on the quality of the book ('Really? That's a very good book. It'd make a terrific --')
Shows discomfort and hesitation to follow Bebe, blinking like a bird
States 'That's Frances. I'm not the cookbook.' indicating a desire to assert her own identity, somewhat curt
Expresses concern about larger societal issues ('But I'm concerned with everything, Mr. Bebe.')
Shows awareness of her image and name, questions decisions about her career and roles, engages in dialogue expressing her views despite discomfort.
Appears uncomfortable and hesitant when led by Bebe, somewhat passive in the face of Bebe’s blunt plans and authoritarian attitude.
Responds honestly about her success being due to luck and hard work, showing humility.
Refuses to accept insincere praise and confronts the judge's wife about her previous hostile behavior, using blunt language.
Sits quietly and calmly when Dick throws a tantrum and hurls things around, showing restraint and not escalating the conflict.
Responds to Dick's anger with a detached, dismissive comment ('My God... I think you're overplaying this a bit...?'), showing emotional distance rather than empathy.
Says 'Goodbye, Dick' after he leaves in anger, indicating finality and possibly a lack of reconciling warmth.
Looks in the mirror and turns it away after not liking her expression, which suggests some self-awareness or introspection but not necessarily warmth toward others.
Returns Odets' tentative, boyish smile; is charmed by his approach.
Engages attentively in conversation with Clurman and Odets; shows interest in the play and role.
Listens intently to Clurman and watches Odets carefully, showing engagement and awareness.
Responds confidently to Clurman that she does not need to be sold on the idea, indicating self-assurance and understanding.
Returns Odets's tentative smile, showing social ease and charm.
Asks clearly about the title of the play with a teasing tone, demonstrating curiosity and confidence.
Denies fear repeatedly and insists on giving her all to the audience with strong conviction and emotional intensity.
Becomes angry and frustrated with Clifford's persistent accusations but ultimately channels that anger into determination to perform well.
Plays along with Clifford's exaggerated act and gracefully begins to leave, showing social awareness and control.
Enters the bedroom scene seemingly captivated by the setting and the kiss, showing emotional engagement but no clear evidence of strategic thinking or skill.
Comes up to Odets, accepts his hug, shares personal and vulnerable feelings in her speech, shows emotion by crying.
Greets Clurman cordially, drinks with him and engages in conversation.
Calls Harry desperately, reveals intense emotional pain and vulnerability about love, sobbing and drinking.
Demands Harry to kill someone she loved and now hates.
Hesitates, then approaches Bebe, wipes mud from face and speaks resolutely about making the best of her situation despite antagonism.
Displays defiance and pride in response to snide remarks, maintains dignity but no clear friendliness or trustworthiness.
Knees the Cop in the balls and bites him while being arrested.
Turns on the motorcycle lights as she passes (a minor provocative act).
Surprised and pleased to see Harry, warmly responds to him.
Joins fight to defend herself instead of letting others fight her battles.
Carries her suitcase toward the house despite noticing a car in driveway with a frown and shrug.
Stares dumbfounded at man who informs her her belongings were moved without her consent.
Frustratedly searches for her diary and demands help finding it on the phone.
Bows grandiloquently to everyone when exiting the stage
Screams and pleads for help while confronted by men breaking into her room
Crying and yelling at cops, showing distress.
Smokes a cigarette and smiles grimly at the sergeant, acting defiant and sarcastic during booking.
Gives sarcastic and insulting answers to the sergeant's questions.
Shakes matrons' hands off her arms, resisting their touch.
Calls out to matrons with humor about wake-up calls and bread and water in bed.
Responds to photographers rudely but with acceptance ('Take me the way I am').
Frightened and shouting for her civil rights and a phone call, lunges at Matrons to make a call
Stiffens when feeling an arm slip around her shoulders, looks alarmed at the two women smiling at her mother
Feels alarmed but accepts being taken into care without resistance; smokes nervously while alone.
Pats her mother on the back a couple of times when hugged
Stares accusingly at Lillian and shows no emotional response to her mother's hug
Warns her mother that she wants to go home, showing a desire for sincere connection
Responds to the doctor's attempts at insight with sarcasm and dismissiveness, refuses to engage sincerely.
Laughs at Lillian's distress and dismisses her plea by mocking 'That's Amelia Earhart!'
Shows suspicion and uncertainty about the injection but listens to the Nurse’s explanation and relaxes somewhat
Expresses appreciation for her mother's visit and fan mail, shows desire to reassure fans.
Laughs off serious concerns, uses dismissive language about accusations involving her mother.
Apologizes for misunderstanding with her mother.
Breaks down and weeps on Harry's shoulder, expresses vulnerability and seeks comfort.
Smiles sarcastically at Symington before being hauled away.
Frowns and reacts nervously but engages with Harry's friendly invitation for a walk.
Deceives attendants by pretending to comply, then suddenly shoves one and commands escape.
Runs and climbs a high wall successfully to escape captivity.
Relies on Harry for help to get over the wall and escape.
Sits up, yawns, stretches, engages in light banter with Harry, and shows some situational awareness regarding location and plans.
Attempts to take control by fiddling with the radio and asks about their location, indicating some initiative and attentiveness.
Expresses confusion about her own state ('I don't know. Not a war exactly. It's more a... a misapprehension maybe...').
Acknowledges a need to talk to her mother despite being told she is not in a clear mental state, suggesting a lack of insight into her situation.
Rubs Harry's neck and looks at him fondly, thoughtfully; cracks a playful joke about his drinking
Cheers with Harry and dances with him, expresses delight and playfulness
Warmly interacts with Harry, confidently waves him off and walks toward the house.
Takes in her mother Lillian in her arms to comfort her during a breakdown.
Declares firmly to Alma Styles to leave Harry out of the discussion despite legal pressures.
Responds reluctantly to her mother's request to play the piano, then abruptly stops and leaves to get some air.
Promises her mother to return by lunch and acknowledges her concerns about drinking with polite affirmations.
Asks her father sincerely what he thinks and seeks his approval, expresses love despite difficult circumstances, shows vulnerability by hiding tears.
Refuses to talk to Lillian's visitor, rejecting communication and support.
Tells her mother to shut up and asserts independence harshly.
Physically wrestles with her mother, twists her wrists, threatens with violence.
Declares she is a grown woman who can decide about her own life.
Assertively refuses to submit to others' demands, insists on her autonomy, and physically overpowers her mother to leave.
Threatens her mother with violence in emotional turmoil.
Denies her illness despite others' concern, rejects help or dialogue.
Acts out a joke for a small audience of devoted drinkers, engaging them with humor.
Turns and looks out the window, noticing the cops arriving calmly after the bar chaos.
Portrays the chaotic bar scene with violence and disruption but shows no intervention or control over the situation.
Responds to Harry's touch and attempts to engage negatively, saying 'Touch me again and I'll kill you, you pig.'
Struggles and moans loudly when injected, showing resistance to treatment.
Responds with hostility and confusion when addressed, unable to engage meaningfully due to heavy sedation.
Struggles and moans loudly when forcibly injected with medication.
Grabs Harry and pleads 'Please! Take me!'
Turns to face the women in their cots and practices a repentant speech admitting her sickness and failures
Collects herself and practices a prepared speech, showing awareness of her situation and planning how to present herself.
Groggily expresses gratitude in a stressful situation, appearing passive and lacking assertiveness.
Neatly stacking dessert dishes and insists on taking care of them despite being told not to
Thanks her mother for understanding her refusal to see her in the hospital
Links arms and hugs her mother, promises to rest
Leaves the house silently at night without saying goodbye
Approaches Harry tentatively and expresses conflicted feelings about people around her
Asks Harry to wait for her despite difficult circumstances, expresses hope and sincerity in their connection.
Shivers and pulls away after a brief hug, indicating discomfort with physical closeness.
Nods casually to a stranger (Hitchhiker) and shares a peaceful moment with gentle, calm exchange.
She smiles, truly grateful when the hitchhiker offers her whiskey.
She tries to warn the hitchhiker about the approaching cops, showing concern for his safety.
Harshly confronts her mother, accuses her of breaking her spirit and refuses to show love or forgiveness.
Expresses strong emotions honestly and makes clear boundaries with those attempting to control her.
Passively endures brutal sexual assault without resistance, repeatedly reciting a phrase to herself.
Responds honestly and sincerely on TV when asked about her mental illness, expressing doubt about her diagnosis.
Responds on the TV show with composure and self-awareness, denying mental illness and critiquing the treatment she received.
Appears uncomfortable, embarrassed and doubtful during the televised recounting of her hardships.
Smiles wearily and accepts congratulations at the show.
Is silent but smiling among a group who talk happily.
Responds vaguely and avoids giving clear information about her ride home.
Turns flatly to Harry York, showing little recognition or warmth.

Expresses concern about how she looked on the show, shares personal losses (mother and father died, sold the house), and engages in a tender, sincere moment holding Harry's hand and speaking about continuing slowly but steadily.
Initially reacts flatly and appears emotionally guarded or evasive (e.g., 'faceless sinner', anger before relaxing), which may signal emotional distance or difficulty connecting in that moment.
Does not pick up on social cues, shows confusion and uncertainty in conversation.
Shows moments of lucidity and attempts to communicate feelings clearly.
Expresses vulnerability and emotional openness, but lacks decisiveness or confident action.
Expresses the last remnant of her indomitable will in words, engages politely and accepts Harry's offer to walk together.
Declines to comment on controversial topic, slinks down in seat to avoid attention.
Carries library books and groceries, interacts with neighborhood children.
Greets Emma politely but receives no response and simply says goodbye.
Responds firmly and distrustfully when Harry grabs her arm and follows her.
Engages cautiously in conversation with Harry, shows some curiosity and even leans in to frisk him before withdrawing embarrassed.
Uses sharp words expressing frustration towards Harry yet acknowledges his presence with some humor and playfulness.
Smiles and recognizes Harry from the newsreel, engages in friendly, somewhat playful banter with him, agrees to keep quiet about sensitive information despite awkwardness.
Recognizes Harry York from the newsreel and connects him to her father's political dealings, demonstrating awareness and social insight.
Engages in the political discussion with caution and some naivety about the repercussions, but she ultimately acknowledges the risks involved, showing some understanding.
Respectfully agrees to keep quiet about sensitive matters after being warned not to speak openly, showing a level of prudence and self-control.
Exchanges awkward and shy social cues with Harry, revealing uncertainty and some social awkwardness.
Intentionally places the bread between her father and her check at the dinner table, possibly highlighting tension or discomfort rather than warmth.
Writes an essay that causes concern, but the action is unintentional and not mischievous; teacher submits it without her initiative.
Intentionally places the bread between her father's check and him at the dinner table, a subtle act of agency and possibly control.
Takes the check, folds it, and puts it in her pocket out of sight.
Acknowledges her role in winning the essay contest but downplays her involvement.
Asks probing questions about Harry York and political affiliations, showing curiosity and critical thinking.
Attempts to explain her honesty and beliefs despite misunderstanding.
Listens and responds respectfully to Lillian's advice, saying 'Yes, Ma.'
Wins a contest and makes a name for herself.
Struggles to explain her honest beliefs clearly to others.
Watches the tense exchange between her parents and visibly disagrees with the lesson her father tries to teach her about staying low and walking away.
Enters on cue, confidently accepts congratulations and mock bows, showing ease and poise on stage.
Pays close attention to her mentor's drunken gesticulations and considers a subscription drive opportunity, showing some interest though doubts her chances of winning.
Expresses doubt about winning the subscription contest but remains intrigued and flattered by prospects of Broadway, showing openness but limited confidence in achieving it.
Quickly diverts attention from her teacher to greet Harry warmly and engages casually, indicating social comfort but not particularly task-oriented competence.
Takes Harry's arm to leave the party when a friend is passed out, showing consideration.
Laughs with Harry at his ironic story, engaging warmly.
Shares personal doubts and desires quietly, showing openness and sincerity.
Does not dominate the conversation, listens to Harry's story attentively.
Looks at Harry, smiles wistfully, and makes a playful, open invitation to skinny dip.
Responds to her mother's worry with a calm and reasoned explanation rather than anger.
Rejects her mother’s offer to help financially, insisting on independence and doing things her own way even if it alienates others.
Initiates a bold, confident move with Harry, suggesting skinny dipping and asserting personal freedom.
Explains her plan to travel and go to New York independently despite her mother's objections, showing determination and self-reliance.
Dismisses her mother's offer of financial help without proposing an alternative solution, potentially risking her goal.
Refuses to yield to her mother's warnings and emotional pleas, showing resolve but also possible stubbornness.
Accepts gifts from the Tall Spectral Man with bewilderment but does not reject him.
Looks tearfully at her mother and father, expresses love sincerely.
Shakes her head sadly and sighs as the bus moves on, showing emotional sensitivity but also a certain resigned distance.
Responds wittily to reporter's question about Stalin by referring to Stanislavski instead.
Accepts gifts from the Tall Spectral Man with bewilderment.
Climbs on the bus despite familial emotional confrontation and mother's threats, showing composure.
Shakes head sadly upon seeing mother's rage, indicating emotional conflict but does not engage further or react impulsively.
Travels to Russia to study at the Moscow Art Theatre, indicating initiative and cultural/skill development.
Returns from Russia aspiring to Broadway, showing ambition and clear career focus.
Appears in a glamorous, artificial Chesterfield advertisement, possibly indicating adaptability and professionalism in commercial work.
Responds to publicist's coached hobbies with ironic remark, 'That's me.'
Calmly processes and discusses disturbing information about Kaminski's death, showing emotional awareness but not panic.
Engages warmly and confidently with Harry, showing social ease and presence of mind.
Asks probing questions about Kaminski's death, indicating curiosity and critical thinking.
Smiles wistfully, squeezes Harry's arm as he hides his disappointment about her relationship.
Politely but persistently points out wardrobe issues to the wardrobe mistress in a friendly manner.
Appears uncomfortable and silent riding with the studio executive, indicating possible insecurity or lack of confidence in the situation.
Being featured prominently on the theatre marquee and drawing a large crowd, suggesting professional recognition and success.
Rolls down her limo window to hear what a derelict with hollow eyes is saying despite studio executive's impatience.
Stares with sympathy at derelicts outside, showing empathy for their plight.
Walks past cheering crowd with glazed eyes, not engaging or acknowledging fans.
Rolls down her limo window to hear a derelict shouting, showing empathy and willingness to engage despite social expectations.
Settles back in her limo seat, not resisting the studio executive who urges leaving promptly.
Responds briefly to reporters with minimal enthusiasm ('It's okay'), suggesting awkwardness or lack of confident engagement in public relations.
Appears glazed and unconcerned walking through the crowd despite their cheers, indicating possible disengagement or uncertainty in managing public attention.
States plainly that her success was due to luck and hard work, showing honesty and realistic self-assessment.
Interrupts the formal occasion by confronting Judge Hillier's Wife with blunt language and accuses the dignitaries of insincerity.
Stops and compassionately gives money and the key to the city to the old Indian beggar, showing kindness and connection.
Engages in lighthearted, friendly banter with Harry on the beach, laughing together.
Refuses to return to the studio despite concern from others, showing stubbornness and distancing herself.
Responds warmly to Harry's comment with a sincere acknowledgment.
Expresses concern about societal suffering and her role, indicating empathy.
Jokes teasingly with Harry and engages playfully on the beach.
Expresses doubts about the quality of the movie and her role in it, showing self-awareness and critical thinking.
Questions how she can continue her career when people are starving, showing moral awareness but uncertainty about practical solutions.
Laughs off the idea of wasting her talent, implying some self-doubt about her capabilities.
Playfully resists Harry's suggestion to ditch the limo, demonstrating confidence and a lively spirit.
Smiles at the makeup man, greets him warmly in the dressing room.
Sarcastically dismisses others' concern about her personal life and politics, rebukes authority with biting humor.
Admits need for time apart and acknowledges relationship difficulties with Dick.
Leaves Dick without direct confrontation but communicates indirectly about plans to leave.
Nods drowsily and admits she has only 'sort of' learned her lines, indicating lack of full preparation.
Responds to unexpected news about her agent and summer stock deal showing some awareness but limited proactive engagement.
Shows emotional vulnerability and hesitancy in interpersonal conversation rather than assertiveness or confidence.
Acknowledges the need for time apart and attempts to communicate this despite tension, indicating some level of emotional intelligence but limited decisiveness.
Does not respond to Dick's emotional outburst, sits calmly and speaks with measured dismissal.
Turns away from her own reflection in the mirror, indicating discomfort with self-image or hesitation.
Sits beside Odets and initiates a gentle greeting, expresses desire to learn and grow as an artist, shows willingness to listen and engage sincerely.
Becomes defensive and insists 'I'm not!' when accused of laziness, indicating frustration rather than openness in that moment.
Acknowledges criticism and expresses desire to learn and grow in her craft.
Is called lazy by Odets and struggles to ignite passion in her performance despite effort.
Plays along with Clifford's exaggerated act, shows playful tolerance in a tense situation.
Smiles tiredly but good-naturedly complies with autograph seekers.
Politely thanks a young admirer and encourages him by suggesting he can see the play in London.
Warns the young man honestly and sincerely about the dangers of Hollywood, showing concern for his future.
Responds sarcastically that broken hearts from her leaving Hollywood "will mend," showing a somewhat detached or dismissive attitude.
Reacts with hostility and insults when the young man questions her personal life, indicating defensiveness and lack of tolerance.
Advises the young man honestly about the dangers of Hollywood and the acting profession, showing clear insight and confidence.
Responds sharply and somewhat defensively to personal questions about her husband and divorce.
Delivers a big, emotional speech confidently after practicing and receiving positive feedback.
Handles an unexpected visitor (Clurman) calmly and engages in conversation while staying observant.
Expresses insecurity about her talent when hearing she won't open in London; challenges the decision and the compromise with anger and disappointment.
Glares at Clurman and hurls a drink in his face in rage after learning she was replaced for money reasons without her consent.
Decides to get out of her contract to avoid studio interference while in London.
Expresses insecure doubt about her own talent when told she won't be opening in London.
Demands practical information and insists on telling Clifford about the situation.
Loses composure and throws a drink in Clurman's face after bad news.
Calls Harry repeatedly to express intense emotions and demands he kill someone for her, showing impulsive, emotional, and irrational behavior rather than clear thinking or confidence.
Sits crying and drinking with a half-packed bag, indicating emotional distress and lack of decisive action or control.
Unfolds a crumpled letter and fixates on its brief and hurtful content, responding with sobbing and statements of hate toward love.
Persists in performing difficult scenes repeatedly, enduring physical discomfort and mud on her face and hair.
Questions the director frustratingly about repeating the takes multiple times.
Confronts Bebe directly, asserting her determination to succeed despite contractual pressures.
Apologizes to Barnes and agrees to try attending the party despite exhaustion.
Jokes self-deprecatingly about being a 'troublesome bitch' and fat.
Expresses trepidation and unease entering the party, wary of attendees.
Expresses tiredness and reluctance to attend the party after a long day but ultimately decides to go and face the situation despite her exhaustion.
Takes pills offered by Barnes, showing willingness to adapt to studio pressures but also reliance on substances as a crutch.
Jokes about her image (troublesome bitch, fat), demonstrating self-awareness and wit despite difficult circumstances.
Looks around the party with trepidation and whispers anxiously, indicating nervousness and possible lack of confidence in the social setting.
Initially resists but then apologizes and agrees to attend the party, showing some ability to accept difficult demands and maintain professionalism.
Thanks Barnes politely after he gives her a drink.
Responds coldly and with sarcasm to the young reporter's inappropriate question.
Is upset and holds in her emotions, showing vulnerability but not directing anger at others.
Drives fast with tears running, sarcastically mocks officer, resists authority, refuses to comply respectfully.

Drives fast and recklessly with tears running down her face, ignores the police officer's command to pull over, argues sarcastically, and switches her headlights back on in a dimout zone despite warnings.
Eventually slows down and hesitates before pulling over when the police officer insists.
Struggles fiercely against the Cop, uses the flashlight as a weapon, kneed him in the groin to escape, and claws at the ground desperately.
Ultimately gets handcuffed and arrested despite struggle.
Calmly writing in her diary after arrest while sitting at her beach house, showing composure.
Engages in a witty, confident conversation with Harry despite difficult circumstances.
Admits to drinking and fighting with a cop, recognizing it as self-destructive behavior.
Expresses insight about human nature and emotional pain, showing thoughtfulness and self-awareness.
Decides not to accompany Harry immediately despite opportunity to leave town, showing hesitation or inability to take action now.
Joins a physical fight to defend herself, refusing to let others fight her battles.
Arrives at her beach house only to find it stripped bare and belongings moved without her knowledge.
Expresses disbelief and frustration but picks up the phone to try to recover her stolen diary.
Responds sarcastically and defensively when reprimanded for being late.
Oversleeps and is late by four hours without prior notice.
Quits abruptly after a confrontation with Tora, causing her physical injury.
Arrives four hours late to set, oversleeps, and responds to criticism with sarcasm rather than accountability.
Asserts herself confidently with the director despite his anger.
Physically lashes out in frustration, causing injury to another crew member and quitting abruptly.
Makes sarcastic and defiant remarks to the judge, mocks courtroom proceedings, and points a finger at the judge calling him a hypocrite.
Accepts sentence of 180 days in jail with a dismissive 'Fine!' indicating lack of fight or strategic response.
Realizes too late that she has no lawyer and tries to assert her civil rights but is ignored, showing lack of preparedness.
Attempts to make a phone call and lunges at Matrons to assert her rights, showing some resourcefulness and refusal to go quietly.
Asks a Matron if she has ever had a broken heart, showing vulnerability.
Wraps a handkerchief around her knuckles and punches the Matron in the jaw.
Calls out to Harry softly and shows a desire for connection.
Fights and lashes out physically, showing aggression instead of warmth.
Dabs at her eyes, then wraps the kerchief around her knuckles and punches the Matron in the jaw, creating a chance to escape.
Attempts to use the phone booths to reach out, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Slumps forward, lower lip trembling, showing emotional collapse and loss of control.
Struggles and fights back against restraint, showing some confidence and agency despite circumstances.
Her shouting 'I have a right! I have a right!' shows grasp of her rights but lacks calmness and persuasion in asserting them.
Stares accusingly at Lillian, not fooled by her enthusiasm.
Does not shake the doctor's hand, showing hesitation or distrust.
Pats her mother on the back a couple of times during hug, showing some restrained interaction.
Warns her mother she wants to go home, clearly communicating her desire despite the situation.
Uses humor and seduction to maintain control in an uncomfortable situation.
Challenges the doctor assertively, refusing to accept his analysis or intervention.
Refuses to engage seriously with professional help, potentially overlooking assistance.
Uses sarcastic and confrontational language toward Symington, mocks his professionalism, challenges his authority.
Engages in a complex interplay of softened tone and hardness, showing some vulnerability mixed with sarcasm.
Refuses to submit quietly, maintains an even gaze and verbal challenge instead of aggression or withdrawal.
Challenges Symington's authority with wit and sarcasm, notices subtle signs like sweat on his lip, maintains composure and control in confrontation.
Refuses to sit down or cooperate as requested, escalating tension instead of calming down.
Lets fan mail from worried supporters drop beside her without engagement.
Remarks to Lillian 'You kill me, Mama' under her breath, showing some restrained familiarity.
Frances shows restlessness and lets fan mail drop without engaging, questions why all letters are opened but does not push further or assertively address the situation.
Fights against the attendants and convulses during the injection, showing resistance though ultimately overcome.
Insults and threatens Dr. Symington aggressively when challenged on her release.
Refuses to accept the doctor's authority and responds with hostility and violence (throwing pencils, pounding intercom).
Controlled sarcastic smile and verbal defiance toward Symington before being sedated.
Wears dark glasses and a big hat to cover her appearance while appearing agitated internally.
Expresses paranoia and distress about being manipulated, showing suspicion and emotional breakdown.
Attempts to communicate her fears clearly to Harry and expresses urgent desire to leave the institution.
Smiles sweetly at Harry, then fiercely pushes the Attendant away to aid escape.
Deceives the Attendant with a seemingly innocent response before acting defiantly.
Teases Harry playfully calling him 'mean man' and 'mean', smiling and engaging in light banter.
Confides in Harry about her feelings and need to talk to her mother despite being under the influence, showing sincerity and vulnerability.
Shows some distance and defensiveness when mentioning her prayers and the concept of misunderstanding, potentially indicating a barrier to warmth.
Leans her head against Harry's shoulder, expresses vulnerability by asking why he leaves her, and shows affection by holding him tight while dancing.
Laughs happily with Harry and shares a tender moment despite his forced smile.
Shows sincere concern for her mother, refusing to give up on her despite difficulty.
Responds warmly to Harry with 'I got your number, Mister Man' and waves him off.
Comforts her mother Lillian by rocking her like a child and saying 'It's okay, Mama. It's okay.'
Defends Harry when Alma Styles implies he is a bad influence, telling her 'You leave him out of this!'
Reluctantly plays a song to please her mother despite personal discomfort, then abruptly stops playing and decides to go out for some air.
Engages in a controlled, calm conversation with her mother about leaving the house, calmly promising to return and gently exiting despite gentle pressure to stay and avoid drinking.
Expresses love to her mother and shares her desire for a simpler, peaceful life.
Firmly tells her mother she is not going to make movies anymore despite pressure.
Decides to quit movies after realizing they make her miserable, expressing clarity and a strong self-awareness about her true desires.
Calmly and confidently communicates her decision to her mother, showing emotional honesty and decisiveness.
Refuses to be pressured by her mother and the agent to return to acting despite external expectations and fan pressure.
Hesitates when expressing her decision initially ('well... I'm not going to make movies anymore'), which may suggest some uncertainty.
Yells and struggles violently but is physically restrained and unable to control the situation.
Is unable to respond satisfactorily to insulin shock treatment as noted by the physician.
Speaks sincerely to Dr. Doyle about profiting from her stay and being ready to move on with life.
Laughs triumphantly after Doctor leaves, defiantly sings to resist discomfort.
Cuts through the doctor's explanations and demands honesty about what she must do to get out.
Demonstrates defiance and resourcefulness by singing to prevent her teeth from chattering after they put a rubber bit in her mouth.
Laughs triumphantly despite her situation, showing confidence in herself.
Refuses to accept the doctor's assessments calmly and instead shows resistance and anger.
Responds to the chant by standing and performing with an exaggerated posture and quiet voice, despite her glazed and expressionless eyes indicating automatic behavior.
Kisses Ernest on the cheek upon arrival home.
Shares tea and answers questions with Lillian despite discomfort.
Admits uncertainty about her future plans, shows humility.
Acknowledges her past mistakes and expresses readiness to face herself and resume her career.
Responds to reporters' questions calmly and with some wit, showing adaptability and social awareness.
Appears uncomfortable and unsure about her future plans, indicating some uncertainty or lack of clear direction.
Acknowledges that only she can change the things done to her, showing self-awareness and acceptance of responsibility.
Asks Harry to wait for her, expresses determination to find him, showing confidence and clear communication.
Shivers and apologizes after brief physical contact, indicating a possible struggle with emotional or physical boundaries.
Leaves a presumably difficult situation on her own initiative, dressed practically and appearing composed in a desolate setting.
Pleading with her father to let her escape, showing vulnerability and desire for autonomy.
Expressing pity for both herself and her father, indicating empathy.
Speaking coldly and detachedly to her mother upon arrival, lacking warmth.
Confronts her mother and others firmly, articulates her feelings clearly and assertively, refuses to be submissive even when being taken away forcibly.
Shows emotional intensity but does not show practical resistance to being taken away, complies by walking out the door.
Sings 'You Are My Sunshine' softly while in a violent ward, showing a gentle and tender moment despite harsh circumstances.
Expresses love and gratitude toward Doyle, saying 'I love you, Harry. I love... Take me home, Harry.' and 'Thank you, Harry.'
Sings steadily and with surprising strength despite being in a harsh mental institution setting.
Is barely conscious and restrained to a bed, showing limited physical agency or interaction.
Expresses clear, coherent speech to Doyle, showing awareness and use of social connection.
Stares mutely, without emotion, at the lobotomy procedure being performed on an adjacent patient.
Turns away and stares at the fan instead of engaging with Dr. Harlington's explanation or resisting the procedure.
No demonstrated initiative or resistance when faced with lobotomy; passive behavior.
Says goodbye politely to Harry and accepts his offer to walk a little way with him, taking his arm in a formal manner.
